Pat.Action: Wakes up the others by gently putting a hand on Sam and saying 'Sam. Wake-up.'
Yanks the keys and kills the local radio
Wakes up anxiously, checks surroundings, notices the van is off-road and the fuel gauge is empty.
Kills the local radio promptly after noticing the critical situation.
Relies on Tiger's response and others rather than taking charge or problem solving himself.
Politely asks if it's ice skating or roller skating, showing interest in Sam's suggestion.
Quietly prepares to siphon gas with Sam without objection or conflict, showing cooperative behavior.
Prepares and uses a siphon kit to siphon gas from an SUV, demonstrating practical and stealthy skill.
Efficiently organizes gear (bicycle, duffel bag, gas can) and plans the task ahead with minimal fuss.
Uses clear reasoning to distinguish between a meaningful quest and a simple errand, showing pragmatic thinking.
Shares grins with Sam during gas siphoning, showing camaraderie.
Signals to pack up and avoid getting caught when parents approach.
Curses when the SUV approaches, indicating frustration but not hostility.
Apologizes sincerely to the Hockey Mom for siphoning gas.
Nods earnestly and accepts the Hockey Mom's scolding respectfully.
Declines the Hockey Mom’s offer for a ride but thanks her politely.
Makes the sign of the cross before resuming pedaling, indicating composure and routine behavior under pressure.
Pushes the van from sunken soil and chases it onto the highway shoulder, showing physical capability and teamwork.
Stands up early, quietly powers down the music, cleans up beer cans, and opens the door for Tad.
Expresses the importance of live music as a shared experience with energy that can’t be replicated virtually
Winces when called out about social media absence, indicating discomfort or possible sensitivity
Expresses thoughtful insights about the importance of live music over virtual presence, showing an understanding of the artistic and experiential aspects of their work.
Uses a moldy bar of soap to scrub his face and has a sharpie drawing on his face, possibly suggesting carelessness or lack of attention to self-presentation.
Drifts and stresses out when asked to name a desert island band, hesitates, does not contribute confidently to conversation.
Questions if the segment will be edited, showing some awareness of the situation.
Lifts the equipment cases into the van, helps with practical tasks without complaint.
Intervenes verbally to deescalate physical violence between Reece and Tad, warns about consequences.
Does not engage in aggressive behavior despite tension, remains calm and practical.
Asks if Tad's cousin is cool, showing interest and consideration about the situation and people involved.
Engages in conversation about the political nature of the venue, showing awareness but no judgment or hostility.
Asks informed questions about security and affiliations of the venue (e.g., SHARP, DMS, Sabre).
Engages in relevant discussion about the gig and venue safety.
Smacks Reece’s arm playfully as they pull out.
Inspects and compliments the flyer, calling it 'Pretty sweet.'
Pounces on Reece playfully after Reece farts, joining in the group's laughter.
Inspects the flyer carefully and offers it to Reece, showing engagement and attention to detail.
Smacks Reece's arm as the van pulls out, indicating casual or playful behavior but no clear signal of competence.
Responds to Reece's intense stare with interest, maintaining social awareness.
Pounces on the flyer after Reece tosses it, joining in on the playful moment.
Calls off Tiger with a look to prevent him from speaking out of turn.
Straps on guitar and scans graffiti carefully, engaging with band environment.
Proposes a dumb idea to the group.
Shares nervous smiles with Sam after a bottle smashes on stage, stays calm on stage despite the chaos.
Searches for Emily among the crowd but cannot find her, then notices Daniel watching him and responds appropriately by joining Sam off-mic for the chorus.
Tunes down his guitar along with Sam, adapting to the change in music style and mood.
Holds up a hand to stop Sam from leaving so Sam can retrieve his phone, saying 'I got you.'
Grabs cases and rolls them out in unison with the band—shows coordination and reliability.
Notices that Sam forgot his phone and immediately offers to go back and retrieve it, demonstrating awareness and helpfulness.
Casually turns the knob and pushes open the green room door after knocking, despite Big Justin's shout to stop—shows confidence but possibly a lack of caution or disregard for authority/instructions.
Immediately tries to call 911 after discovering Emily with a knife in her skull.
Yanks the charger from Sam’s phone without asking, interrupting the silence in the room.
BOLTS to the door with the phone to get help despite physical confrontation from Big Justin and Gabe.
Immediately attempts to call 911 after discovering the stabbing, takes urgent action despite chaos.
Runs through the venue navigating obstacles while trying to make the call.
Is physically overpowered; phone is knocked away preventing the emergency call.
No actions or statements present in the excerpt to evaluate competence.
Repeatedly demands to know where the cops are, insisting on their presence for a safer resolution.
Supports opening the door only for a cop, or keeping bullets in the gun for protection.
Insists on opening the door only for the police or keeping bullets in the gun, asserting a cautious and controlled stance.
Asks repeatedly 'Where are the cops?' displaying urgency but potentially lacking strategic input beyond that.
Helps move the couch to block the door with Amber, cooperating to secure the situation.
Motions for Sam to lower the barrel of the gun, signaling a desire to reduce hostility or danger.
Helps Tiger to the couch, showing care and attentiveness.
Fumbles with the revolver, indicating nervousness or uncertainty but still taking part in protecting the group.
Refuses to take the revolver and explicitly says 'Can’t shoot.'
Asks Amber if there is another way out, showing concern for alternatives beyond violence.
Refuses to take the gun and shoot despite the tension, showing self-awareness and restraint.
Asks Amber if there is another way out, actively seeking alternatives.
Asks Amber about her phone to help, gestures respectfully to the corpse, asks permission to search her, shows concern and reverence.
Searches the corpse's pockets, cooperates with the group, shares findings, tries to make sense of clues in a calm manner.
Orders Big Justin to empty his pockets after he insults him, maintains control without escalating conflict.
Takes initiative to search the corpse despite hesitation from Amber, showing leadership and decisiveness.
Finds a folded napkin with a cryptic word and brings it to group's attention, demonstrating observational skill and communication.
Suggests and participates in logical actions like searching, interpreting clues, and questioning Big Justin, showing situational awareness and strategic thinking.
Sets out items found (lighter, cigarettes) possibly with an implied strategic thought (e.g., fire), indicating tactical thinking.
Does not appear to take precaution against potential dangers like asbestos or hostile reactions beyond ordering the search, indicating a slight omission in risk management.
Throws napkin at Big Justin and commands him to empty pockets, adopting an assertive, commanding role, indicating confidence and control.
Curses himself after Big Justin smashes the phone, showing frustration but no aggression toward others.
Commands to aim at the door during a tense situation, demonstrating protectiveness and readiness to defend the group.
Commands Big Justin to 'Turn ‘em out,' showing decisiveness and leadership in a tense situation.
Curses himself after Big Justin snaps the phone in half, suggesting frustration at a blown opportunity.
Orders to 'Aim at the door' during the blackout, indicating a clear-headed and tactical response under pressure.
Elects to be the single voice communicating with Darcy, inches closer to the door to engage in negotiation.
Clearly and calmly states that they have a loaded gun, demonstrating honesty and straightforwardness.
Looks back to the band for consensus but receives none, showing awareness of group dynamics but perhaps a lack of leadership to secure agreement.
Responds with 'No shit!' revealing some frustration but maintaining confrontation during a tense negotiation.
Attempts to negotiate for a phone and ensures safety by proposing to hand over the gun only if they get a cell phone; shows concern for group's leverage and safety.
Consults group and seeks consensus before approaching door, showing respect and inclusiveness.
Focuses on tactical and practical concerns, no explicit friendly or warm expressions observed in this excerpt.
Grabs Tiger’s shoulders to calm him down and encourages buying time instead of panic.
Leads group discussion asking for ideas and trying to manage the tense situation.
Firmly negotiates handing over the gun but insists on keeping the ammo, showing both cooperation and caution.
Asks the group for smart ideas and attempts to keep control of the situation by negotiating and buying time.
Intervenes physically to calm Tiger down, showing presence of mind under stress.
Agrees to hand over the gun but insists on keeping the ammo, indicating tactical thinking.
Expresses uncertainty about the situation but still tries to lead the group.
Asks others to step back for safety before handling a gun, carefully unloads rounds into Sam's hands.
Shoots an item Darcy values despite her warning.
Commands others to step back, safely unloads revolver, carefully opens locked door while maintaining a sturdy stance and cautious posture.
Refuses Darcy's request to approach, preferring to throw instead, indicating situational judgment.
Fails to notice or avoid the hand grabbing his wrist when opening the door, leading to potential compromise.
Struggles fiercely to protect himself and others during the violent confrontation, showing determination and resilience.
Crumples in pain and expresses distress after being injured, indicating vulnerability and sincerity.
Attempts to fire a gun but it clicks without firing; struggles physically against attackers but ultimately injured and overwhelmed.
Fights to maintain leverage against attackers and tries to hold the door closed despite injury.
Shows panic verbally ('Oh god. Oh no...'), indicating emotional overwhelm after being injured.
Remains composed and repeats 'Okayokayokayokay' to likely manage the situation despite visible distress and severe injury.
Allows Tiger to tightly wrap a tube sock above his elbow to control bleeding, cooperating in first aid despite the pain and shock.
Shows vulnerability through grunts, sobs, and spits, indicating the severity of wounds but stays present in the moment instead of freezing or panicking.
Clutches his wound, blood seeping through the jacket, does not attempt to fix or indicate a plan to manage the injury or help himself further
Allows Tiger to wrap his jacket around his mangled arm, implicitly relying on others for medical aid
Admits to losing the gun but held on longer than others expected.
Gives a drowsy smile after losing the gun, showing possible lack of alertness or energy.
Huddled against the wall with labored breaths, defers to others for information and action.
Offers to be informed and stays ready to assist despite physical state.
Eager presence among the group despite serious injury.
Keeps gritting teeth and tolerates pain silently, not complaining or causing trouble for others.
Shows eagerness and stays engaged in the operation despite dangerous conditions.
Has a severely injured hand with exposed tendons and losing blood fast, suggesting poor personal safety or lack of caution.
Expresses concern that they can’t just go missing and need to be found.
Tries to lighten the mood by comparing the dangerous situation to paintball and shares a personal story about feeling afraid.
Suggests treating the dangerous situation like a paintball game, sharing relevant personal experience with ex-Marines and the importance of not taking it too seriously.
Admits to cowering behind trees and being ineffective in the paintball game, implying past fear and lack of skill.
(waving off concern) 'I’m just gonna run.'
Waves off concerns and decides confidently to run, showing decisiveness.
Observes and acknowledges that they were well equipped ('They loaded us out'), demonstrating awareness of their preparedness.
Snatches the microphone from the stand and uses it to create loud feedback, saving Amber from the attacking dog.
Snatches the microphone from the stand and uses it to create ear-splitting feedback, causing Brownie to release Amber.
Identifies and confirms the song name on the set list, assisting Sam in understanding the set list under pressure.
Moves with the others to barricade the door, actively participating in their defense.
Does not intervene or take charge despite Sam fumbling the extinguisher situation; remains passive during crisis.
Steps back calmly as others prepare to defend against the door being kicked in.
Holds up the napkin as evidence, looks to Amber to connect the dots.
Stays involved and attentive during a tense confrontation, showing engagement and sincerity.
Calls out for Sam upon entering an empty lab, showing concern or hope.
Remains silent and passive after being lowered into the lab, avoiding confrontation or engagement.
Is lowered carefully into the underground lab by another character, indicating vulnerability or reliance on others for physical support.
Calls out 'Sam?' in the empty lab, showing initiative and attempt to communicate despite isolation.
Reassures others by saying 'It's okay' despite the tense situation.
Acknowledges the difficulty but expresses group loyalty with 'he's with us. We gotta split.'
Offers to have Daniel help with the escape plan despite uncertainty around Daniel's loyalty.
Reacts calmly when finding the empty lab, acknowledges the situation but remains focused on the task of splitting and moving forward.
Assesses the situation with the industrial fan and concludes they won’t fit through it, showing practical spatial judgment.
Suggests Daniel can help despite unknowns about him, showing some trust but also possible gap in full risk assessment.
Jumps and drops the box-cutter reflexively after Daniel is killed, then grabs Daniel’s machete and attacks the Bartender to protect the group.
Jumps and drops the box-cutter when Daniel is shot unexpectedly.
Quickly grabs Daniel's machete and reflexively attacks the Bartender, successfully incapacitating him.
Pockets some shot shells and promptly hands over two shells to Amber when requested, supporting the team's defense efforts.
Shouts encouragement to Sam during a chaotic and dangerous situation, urging him to act quickly.
Pockets some shot shells off the bar and promptly hands over two shells to Amber when requested, enabling her to reload quickly.
Responds affirmatively and supports the group’s move towards exit with coordinated momentum, showing readiness and alertness.
Shouts encouragement to Sam during a tense moment, attempting to prompt action.
Does not take direct control or initiative in the shootout scene, mostly supporting roles and reacting to others’ moves.
Pulls Amber back through the entrance and sets her on the couch.
Questions Amber about her experiences with a tone that could be seen as challenging or dismissive.
Uses humor and sarcasm in a tense moment ('Fuck yourself' said kindly) to perhaps defuse tension and bond with Amber.
Shares a personal story about being frustrated with family over something trivial, shows vulnerability by admitting strong emotions.
Expresses concern that he cannot die with Amber, indicating emotional attachment and care.
Admits to fear and cowering during paintball against skilled opponents, showing honesty and humility.
Reflects on a past failure in a paintball game against skilled opponents and admits to cowering rather than leading or fighting back.
Acknowledges the severity of their situation calmly without panic despite being injured and in a hopeless setting.
Expresses emotional vulnerability and frustration about personal family events rather than focusing on immediate problem-solving.
Acknowledges the danger of real guns and refuses to engage in 'real war' play, showing awareness and prudence.
Engages in discussion about the impossibility of playing real war with real guns, indicating realistic judgment.
Disguises himself with face paint and wears a jacket to impersonate a threat, then drops into a hole confidently, navigating the underground lab.
Leaves hair clippings littering the floor, indicating a lack of preparedness or attention to detail.
Creeps behind Jonathan in war paint with machete raised, attempts to engage but then scrambles back as bullets whiz and ricochet; falters and cowers behind a container wall.
Speaks quietly through the floor to Amber, first calling her but then dismissing it with 'Nevermind...', then rises to his feet.
Turns out pockets, drops shotgun shells, loads and fires shotgun under pressure.
Turns out pockets to hand over shells, quickly reloads and fires one-handed mid-flinch.
Clings to the shotgun defensively and suffers a violent struggle with Jonathan.
Looks pained but shows relief when Amber shoots Jonathan, showing reliance and trust in companion.
Allows Amber to help him to his feet after the fight, indicating mutual support and openness.
Engages in brief, strained communication with Gabe and Amber post-conflict.
Fires shotgun mid-flinch and misses by a mile.
Clings on for life during a struggle with Jonathan.
Recovers with help from Amber and gets to feet after the fight.
Heads off and picks up the paper scrap (Tad’s flyer) showing attentiveness to surroundings and preserving a clue.
Suggests staying quiet until they’re out, showing prudence and concern for group safety.
Asks Gabe if he saw them die, showing concern about traumatic events and empathy for others.
Mentions leaving ('Think I'm going...') after a tense conversation, potentially indicating withdrawal or avoidance.
Takes out a .25 handgun and cautiously approaches to monitor a tense situation, focusing on safety and control.
Suggests to Amber that she should go with them to 'hedge bets', showing concern for her safety.
Quietly observes disturbing scene, fights gag reflex, showing restraint and composed demeanor.
Trains weapon on Alan and Amber while confirming if they have the dog, showing protective behavior and situational awareness.
Firmly confronts Clark with 'Police or murder,' indicating a serious but controlled approach to conflict.
Takes the .25 pistol from his belt and cautiously approaches, training it on Alan while coordinating with Amber who has the shotgun, demonstrating tactical awareness and readiness.
Suggests to Amber that she should go along to 'hedge their bets,' showing strategic thinking and prudence.
Calmly demands confirmation of threat ('You got the dog?') and identifies presence as police or murder, indicating situational awareness and clear communication.
Jumps in shock when Clark is shot, voice carries with shock and adrenaline, shows emotional reaction to the carnage
Misses Darcy with a gunshot and accidentally hits him in the back
Attempts to communicate and asks Darcy if he has a cell phone, shows some concern about communication
Jumps immediately when Amber shoots Clark; reacts quickly to chaos and trauma.
Swallows, turns to look at carnage, admits 'this IS A NIGHTMARE' openly showing shock and adrenaline.
Asks if Darcy has a cell phone, attempts to use resources thoughtfully after shooting.
Misses a shot with the .25, kicking up dirt.
Successfully hits Darcy in the back with a shot.
Hits Darcy in the eyebrow with a gunshot, effectively stopping him.
Approaches Darcy cautiously with guns raised, then lowers weapon when Darcy fades.
Raises gun quickly when spotting the wounded dog approaching, showing awareness and readiness.
Slumps back quietly after the threat passes, demonstrating calmness and emotional control.
Makes an obscure, somewhat dismissive comment about their 'desert island band' after a tense moment.
Calls off Tiger with a look before he speaks up.
Asks Sam 'You okay?', showing concern.
Notices Tiger’s discomfort at the swastika graffiti but does not react strongly or confront it.
Helps slide the couch with Amber to blockade the door, showing quick thinking and teamwork.
Rushes to dig cartridges from Big Justin’s pocket and actively loads the revolver under Reece’s direction.
Motions for Sam to lower the gun barrel when aiming at Justin, indicating situational awareness and control.
Fumbles with the revolver initially, indicating nervousness or lack of skill.
Holds up the napkin as evidence and tries to clarify a key detail by linking it to Amber.
Does not directly intervene physically or challenge Daniel at a critical moment despite the escalation.
Pulls Amber back through the entrance and shuts the door, helping to secure their position.
Sets Amber on the couch and goes to get water, showing presence of mind and care in a stressful situation.
Questions Amber about her experiences and the situation with some skepticism and insight.
Reflects on the situation calmly, noting the impact of cell phones on their predicament.
Engages in a hostile exchange with Amber using sarcasm and swearing.
Asks if anyone can hot-wire a car, showing practical problem-solving thinking.
Suggests staying quiet until they are out, demonstrating cautious and strategic behavior.
Heads off and picks up the paper scrap with the flyer, showing alertness and attention to detail.
Questions what others are doing and whether they saw deaths, showing situational awareness and concern.
Slumps back quietly with Amber after the pit bull passes, showing a moment of shared calm and acknowledgment.
Raises gun alongside Amber towards the wounded pit bull, indicating readiness to potentially harm despite the animal's suffering.
